reference_soap:
S: The patient, a flooring installer with no significant past medical history, presents with painless blurry vision in the right eye for one week, intermittent fevers, headaches, body aches, and a nonpruritic maculopapular rash on the lower legs for six months. The patient also reports an isolated episode of left knee and testicular swelling in the past but denies any neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting, Raynauds phenomenon, oral ulcerations, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or photosensitivity. No history of exposure to toxic substances or habits related to smoking, drinking, or illicit drug use.
O: Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals bilateral papilledema, greater optic nerve erythema in the right eye, a right inferior nasal quadrant visual field defect, and a right afferent pupillary defect. Muscle strength, reflexes, and sensation to light touch, pinprick, vibration, and proprioception are intact. A maculopapular rash is noted on bilateral lower extremities. Lab findings include microcytic anemia Hemoglobin: 11.6 gmdL, Hematocrit: 35.3, MCV: 76.9 fL, hyponatremia Sodium: 133 mmolL, elevated ESR 33 mmhr, and CRP 13.3 mgL. Urinalysis is normal. Lumbar puncture shows clear fluid, 2 RBCsL, and 56 WBCsL.
A: The patients symptoms and findings suggest a possible inflammatory or infectious process affecting multiple systems, including the central nervous system, as indicated by papilledema and abnormal lumbar puncture results. Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune conditions, infectious diseases, or other systemic inflammatory disorders. The presence of optic nerve involvement and systemic symptoms necessitates further investigation to narrow down the causes.
P: Plan to conduct additional diagnostic tests to explore underlying causes, including imaging studies and specific serological tests. Consultation with a neurologist and possibly a rheumatologist or infectious disease specialist is recommended. Monitor the patients symptoms closely and provide supportive care as needed. Educate the patient about the findings and the importance of follow-up for further evaluation and management. Ensure the patient understands the potential seriousness of the symptoms and the need for thorough investigation and possibly long-term management.

reference_soap:
S: The patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness, reporting a previously failed right cochlear implant. He denies experiencing discomfort during the recent MRI procedure.
O: Recent MRI with airway secured using a 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT. Pre-operative preparations for ABI insertion include intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring and placement of various electrodes for nerve monitoring. The anesthesia plan includes Total Intravenous Anesthesia TIVA with propofol targeted at a plasma concentration of 3.55.0 mcgml and remifentanil dosed at 0.080.3 mcgkgmin.
A: Primary diagnosis is congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness with a failed right cochlear implant. The patient is scheduled for ABI insertion with comprehensive intraoperative monitoring to ensure nerve integrity and anesthesia efficacy.
P: Proceed with ABI insertion under TIVA. Monitor intraoperative neurophysiology closely. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of recovery and necessary follow-up care. Educate the patient and family on post-operative care and encourage them to reach out with any concerns or questions.

[Patient]: Alright, doctor.

Intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring will include brainstem auditory sensory evoked potentials, brainstem mapping of CN IX, X, XI, and XII, and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential MEP. S: The patient reported undergoing an ultrasound in April 2017, which identified a thyroid nodule in the left lobe. The patient underwent biochemical screening, including TSH, autoantibodies, and calcitonin levels, which showed elevated calcitonin. A stimulation test with intravenous calcium indicated significantly elevated calcitonin levels, leading to a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection. Post-surgery, the patient experienced transient hypocalcemia but recovered within 48 hours. The patient inquired about the recovery and results of the tissue tests post-surgery.
O: Ultrasound revealed a 1 cm thyroid nodule in the left lobe. Initial calcitonin level was 40 ngmL normal range 1-4.8 ngmL. Post-stimulation, calcitonin levels peaked at 1420 ngmL. Postoperative recovery included slight hypocalcemia, resolving in 48 hours. Immunohistochemistry of the thyroid nodule confirmed medullary thyroid cancer MTC, 1 cm in size, with cells positive for calcitonin, Cromogranin A, Synaptofisin, and TTF-1, and negative for amyloid. No lymph node metastases were found. Additional tissue analysis involved antigen retrieval and immunolabeling confirming MTC.
A: The primary diagnosis is medullary thyroid cancer, confirmed by histological and immunohistochemical analysis of the thyroid nodule and absence of metastasis in lymph nodes. The patients elevated calcitonin levels and the results of the stimulation test supported the need for surgical intervention, which was successfully performed without complications.
P: The patient will continue with regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or progression of medullary thyroid cancer. Monitoring will include periodic calcitonin levels and ultrasound imaging of the neck. The patient will be educated on the signs of recurrence and the importance of adherence to follow-up schedules. Further genetic counseling may be considered to evaluate for familial MTC.

reference_soap:
S: The patient reports a progressive headache, nausea, vomiting, right-side weakness, ptosis, and diplopia for about a week. The patient also experienced an acute onset of conscious disturbance, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of E3VaM5.
O: Initial brain CT revealed an enhanced brain tumor in the left temporal lobe with necrotic cystic changes, upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift. Post-operative pathology confirmed a diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme GBM. Follow-up MRI in June 2014 showed a new 1.1 cm nodular lesion at the left temporal base, which progressed to 3.0 cm by October 2014. Histology post-second surgery showed oligodendroglial components with IDH1 positivity, diffuse p53 positivity, and MGMT negativity. The third surgery pathology revealed GBM- and PNET-like components with positivity for synaptophysin and CD56.
A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent glioblastoma multiforme GBM, with differential diagnosis including primitive neuroectodermal tumor PNET components. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive and recurrent nature of the tumor.
P: The plan includes close monitoring of the patients condition with regular follow-ups to assess for further progression or new symptoms. Continued treatment options will be considered based on the evolution of the disease and the patients response to previous therapies. Education on symptom management and potential side effects of treatments will be provided to ensure the patient remains informed about their care.

reference_soap:
S: The patient, a post-liver transplant recipient, reports severe abdominal pain and has a history of hepatocellular carcinoma. Recently diagnosed with severe acute pancreatitis, the patient experienced some relief from pain with fentanyl infusion but still describes the pain as quite painful. Symptoms of nausea, vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness were noted upon opioid discontinuation.
O: The patient was initially managed with a continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion, starting at 1200 gday and increased to 2400 gday based on pain intensity. Following the discontinuation of fentanyl, withdrawal symptoms including nausea, vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness occurred. These symptoms resolved upon resuming fentanyl at 240 gday. A transdermal fentanyl patch was later used to taper the opioid more gradually. The patients pancreatitis recurred transiently, requiring resumption and gradual tapering of fentanyl infusion from 600 gday to 60 gday over several days. The patient reports feeling much better following the complete discontinuation of fentanyl, 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute pancreatitis post-liver transplantation, complicated by opioid withdrawal symptoms following fentanyl discontinuation. The patients response to the reintroduction and gradual tapering of fentanyl suggests effective management of withdrawal symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the patients symptoms and recovery post-pancreatitis and post-fentanyl discontinuation. Follow-up appointments should be scheduled regularly to assess pain levels, pancreatitis status, and any potential recurrence of symptoms. Education on recognizing signs of pancreatitis and opioid withdrawal should be provided. Referral to a pain management specialist and a gastroenterologist for ongoing pancreatitis management and to address any complications from liver transplantation may be necessary. Ensure compliance with the prescribed pain management and withdrawal tapering protocols.

reference_soap:
S: The patient, a non-smoker and engineer, reported experiencing right chest pain. He denied any exposure to asbestos and any history of smoking. The patient also mentioned a significant drop in forced vital capacity over the past three years and recent development of shortness of breath on exertion.
O: Physical examination revealed reduced lung sounds at the right lung base. Chest X-ray indicated a considerable reduction in right lung volume with associated right pleural effusion. CT scan confirmed these findings and also showed pleural thickening. Serological, autoimmune, and microbiological tests were negative. PET-CT showed low-intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-FDG in the right pleura. Surgical lung biopsy identified non-specific fibrinous pleurisy without neoplastic or infectious cells. The patients condition progressed to restrictive respiratory failure.
A: The primary diagnosis is non-specific fibrinous pleurisy with associated pleural effusion and pleural thickening, leading to restrictive respiratory failure. Differential diagnoses such as mesothelioma, tuberculosis, and pneumothorax were ruled out through various investigations. The prognosis became poor as the patient developed restrictive respiratory failure and subsequently suffered a fatal cardiac ischemic attack.
P: Management included a course of prednisolone to address inflammation and symptoms. Continuous monitoring and regular follow-ups were recommended to manage the progression of respiratory failure. Education on symptom management and the importance of reporting any new symptoms was provided. A surgical lung biopsy was performed to further investigate the pleural changes. Unfortunately, despite these measures, the patients condition deteriorated, leading to his death. An autopsy confirmed the absence of mesothelioma or other pleural neoplastic diseases, but showed diffuse fibrinous pleurisy.

reference_soap:
S: The patient presented with body weight loss and has a history of well-controlled hypertension and diabetes. He reported undergoing various treatments and procedures for a diagnosed sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma.
O: Laboratory tests showed decreased hemoglobin at 9.1 gdl normal range: 13.8-17.2 gdl for men, 12.1-15.1 gdl for women. Tumor markers were within normal limits. Colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the sigmoid colon, confirmed as RAS-mutant adenocarcinoma by biopsy. CT scans indicated irregular colonic wall thickening, involvement of the urinary bladder, and enlarged regional lymph nodes suggestive of metastases, but no distant metastasis. The patient was diagnosed as LACC stage IIIC T4bN2M0. Post-treatment follow-up showed significant tumor shrinkage and no recurrence at 16 months post-diagnosis.
A: The primary diagnosis is locally advanced colorectal cancer LACC stage IIIC T4bN2M0, with a post-treatment stage of ypT4b, ypN0, M0, ypStage IIC. Differential diagnoses were considered based on tumor markers and imaging but were ruled out by biopsy and further pathological examination.
P: The patient underwent a loop transverse colostomy and received 6 courses of CAPOX plus bevacizumab, with modifications due to neurotoxicity. This was followed by sigmoid colectomy and partial bladder resection. Postoperative recovery was uneventful. He completed 8 courses of adjuvant chemotherapy with capecitabine. Ongoing monitoring and supportive care will continue to manage and prevent potential recurrence.

Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits such as multiple sclerosis or a neoplastic process, though imaging did not support these.

Regular follow-ups to monitor the progression of the spinal stenosis and adjust the treatment plan as necessary are essential. Education regarding the condition and its implications will be provided to ensure the patient and his family understand the treatment goals and prognosis.

Ultrasound at 34 weeks indicated an estimated fetal weight in the 94th percentile with normal placental vascular resistance.
A: The primary diagnosis is significant infrarenal aortic stenosis with differential diagnoses including congenital abdominal coarctation, Takayasus arteritis, fibromuscular dysplasia, aortic neurofibromatosis, aortic tuberculosis, and radiation aortitis. The presence of well-developed collateral vasculature suggests a chronic aortopathy, likely due to congenital abdominal aortic coarctation, fibromuscular dysplasia, or an inactive form of Takayasus arteritis.
P: Continue monitoring the patients pregnancy and headaches, along with potential symptoms related to aortic stenosis. Maintain current medication regimen of aspirin and calcium. Regular follow-up appointments are essential to monitor the progression of the aortic condition and manage pregnancy-related complications. The patient is advised to immediately report any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing bothersome pain in the right upper abdomen. The patient has a history of cholelithiasis and was referred for further evaluation and possible surgical treatment.

P: The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy with removal and ligation of the ARHD. Post-operative recovery includes regular follow-ups to monitor healing and adherence to post-operative instructions. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms or concerns during recovery.

S: 50-year-old African American female presents with a three-week history of intractable headache, confusion, vertical binocular diplopia, photophobia, and difficulty with balance. No significant past medical history was provided during the consultation.
O: Examination findings include best corrected visual acuities of 2025 in the right eye and 2020 in the left eye, intraocular pressures of 14 mmHg in both eyes, and no afferent pupillary defect. Extraocular motility and confrontational visual fields were full. Funduscopic examination revealed grade-four optic disc edema, blurring of the optic disc margin, and obscuration of vasculature with preretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages in both eyes. Optical coherence tomography confirmed optic nerve swelling. Fluorescein angiography showed hyperfluorescence of the optic disc in both eyes. Head CT, brain MRI, and MRV were unremarkable. CSF analysis showed an opening pressure of 30 cm H2O, 77 white blood cellsmm3 with 94 lymphocytes, 93 mgdL protein, and 73 mgdL glucose. Bacterial and fungal cultures, as well as tests for Lyme, syphilis, herpes simplex virus, West Nile virus, enterovirus, ANA, p-ANCA, and a respiratory viral panel, were all negative.
A: The patients clinical presentation and diagnostic findings suggest a primary diagnosis of Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension IIH, also known as pseudotumor cerebri. The differential diagnosis includes other causes of increased intracranial pressure, but negative imaging and specific tests help rule out secondary causes.
P: The management plan will include weight management advice and possibly a prescription for acetazolamide to reduce cerebrospinal fluid production and alleviate symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor her symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms promptly. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management is also planned.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old woman with a history of stage IIB non-small cell lung cancer NSCLC in the left upper lobe, previously treated with neoadjuvant carboplatin, pemetrexed, and radiotherapy. She reports severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia.
O: Examination and imaging revealed that the NSCLC has attached to the T2 and T3 vertebrae and infiltrated the corresponding nerve roots, without direct invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. MRI studies were utilized to assess the extent of tumor involvement.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIB NSCLC with vertebral and nerve root involvement by the tumor. The symptoms of pain and paresthesia are attributed to this involvement. Differential diagnosis would consider other causes of neuropathy and bone pain, but imaging and clinical presentation strongly support the primary diagnosis.
P: The management plan includes a posterior approach, image-guided T2 and T3 osteotomy, and transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor to address the tumor attachment and infiltration. The patient has consented to the surgery. Post-operative care will involve spine navigation and specific surgical techniques to avoid further nerve damage. Follow-up care instructions will be provided post-operation to ensure a smooth recovery. Referral to pain management and physical therapy will be considered post-surgery to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old woman who presented with chest distress lasting 11 hours, shortness of breath at rest, and difficulty lying in the recumbent position. She has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, for which she takes oral medications. She reports relief of initial symptoms post coronary angiography and stent implantation but developed hematochezia on the third day post-operation without abdominal pain.
O: Initial examination post-admission led to a diagnosis of coronary atherosclerotic heart disease. Treatment included coronary angiography, stent implantation, and administration of heparin 2000 units arterial intrathecal and 3500 units intravenous. Post-procedure medications were aspirin 100 mgday, TiGraylo 90 mg every 12 hours, and enoxaparin sodium 0.4 mL every 12 hours subcutaneously for 3 days. On the third day post-operation, the patient developed hematochezia. Examination revealed mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant, peritoneal irritation signs, and a neoplasm-like mucous clot in the anus. Lab tests showed hemoglobin at 102 gL normal: 120-160 gL, prothrombin time 13.4 s normal: 11-13.5 s, and INR 1.2. Colonoscopy identified a submucosal mass in the sigmoid colon with a partially ruptured mucous membrane. Abdominal CT scan confirmed a submucosal hematoma in the sigmoid colon and thickening at the left flexure of the colon.
A: The primary diagnosis is coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, complicated by post-operative hematochezia likely due to anticoagulation therapy. Differential diagnosis includes gastrointestinal neoplasm versus hematoma secondary to anticoagulation. The prognosis depends on the management of the gastrointestinal complications and the underlying heart disease.
P: The initial management included discontinuation of anticoagulants, administration of total parenteral nutrition, and close monitoring. Given the lack of resolution of clinical symptoms with conservative treatment, further evaluation and possible intervention for the sigmoid colon issue are planned. Continued cardiovascular management with adjustments to anticoagulation therapy will be necessary, considering the gastrointestinal risks. Patient education regarding signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and the importance of follow-up appointments will be emphasized. Referral to gastroenterology for further assessment and management of the sigmoid colon condition is indicated.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old postmenopausal woman who was asymptomatic prior to a screening colonoscopy that revealed an adenocarcinoma. She has a surgical history of hysterectomy due to symptomatic fibroids and no family history of cancer. She was unaware of any symptoms or palpable masses before the colonoscopy.
O: Immunohistochemistry of the colonic lesion showed positive results for CK-7, GATA-3, and ER, weakly positive for MOC-31, and negative for CK-20, CD-X2, PR, PAX-8, SOX-10, CD45, chromogranin, synaptophysin, and TTF-1, suggesting a breast primary. Screening mammography was normal. CT and PET-CT scans showed osteolytic lesions in thoracic vertebrae and pelvis, and bilateral axillary adenopathy. Fine needle aspiration of the right axillary lymph node was negative for malignancy. CEA, CA 19-9, and CA-125 levels were within normal limits. A bone biopsy confirmed metastatic breast invasive ductal carcinoma.
A: Primary diagnosis is metastatic breast invasive ductal carcinoma, initially presenting as an adenocarcinoma detected during a colonoscopy. The immunohistochemistry and imaging studies support the diagnosis of a breast primary with metastasis to bone and lymph nodes.
P: The patient will continue regular follow-ups with the oncologist to monitor the condition and discuss treatment options. Anastrozole therapy will be continued until further assessment. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns during her visits and to maintain a strong support system, involving her family in discussions with her healthcare team. Regular imaging and lab tests will be scheduled to monitor the progression or regression of the disease.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain and swelling in the right submandibular region for approximately 10 days. The symptoms are intermittent, worsening during meals and resolving post-meal. The patient also experiences discomfort when consuming sour or acidic foods.
O: Clinical examination revealed visible swelling in the right submandibular region without any discharge. Bimanual palpation identified a firm swelling in the posterior floor of the mouth. A preliminary diagnosis of right submandibular salivary gland sialolithiasis was made, pending confirmation via computed tomography CT scan. The suspected calculi measured approximately 7 mm.
A: The primary diagnosis is right submandibular salivary gland sialolithiasis, based on the clinical findings and patients symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of salivary gland swelling such as infections or tumors, but these are less likely given the described symptoms and clinical findings.
P: The management plan includes obtaining a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis. If confirmed, surgical removal of the submandibular gland will be necessary. The procedure will involve a Risdon incision, with careful handling of the marginal mandibular nerve and division of the submandibular duct. Postoperative care will include placement of a suction drain and layered wound closure to minimize complications. The patient will be scheduled for follow-up evaluations to monitor recovery. Education regarding the procedure and postoperative care will be provided to ensure the patients understanding and compliance.

Uses albuterol inhaler as needed. Reports previous stable condition with tadalafil and macitentan treatment for PAH, but symptoms have worsened recently. Discontinued mycophenolate mofetil 6 years ago due to concerns about reactivating Lyme disease.

Patient started on subcutaneous treprostinil 3 months ago due to progressive symptoms.

Differential diagnosis could include exacerbation of ILD or complications from PAH. Prognosis depends on response to adjusted treatment regimen and close monitoring.

Educate patient on the importance of adhering to treatment and attending regular check-ups. Consider re-evaluation of ILD status if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, a 34-year-old female, presents with a four-day history of fever, muscle pain, and vomiting. She reports increased thirst, frequent urination, nocturia, and unintentional weight loss over the past month. She denies any underlying diseases, family history of diabetes, and use of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

Laboratory tests reveal a venous plasma glucose level of 467 mgdL, wide anion gap metabolic acidosis, and elevated serum beta-hydroxybutyrate, consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis DKA. An electrocardiogram indicates sinus tachycardia, and a chest X-ray is normal. Additional tests confirm a dengue infection with features of dengue hemorrhagic fever DHF, including hemoconcentration, thrombocytopenia, and vaginal bleeding. After treatment initiation, the patient developed chest discomfort, puffy eyelids, and mild pitting edema in both legs, with bilateral hilar congestion on a follow-up chest X-ray.
A: The primary diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis, complicated by newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus. Concurrently, the patient is diagnosed with dengue hemorrhagic fever. The patients symptoms of chest discomfort and edema following fluid administration suggest fluid overload, possibly leading to leakage syndrome.
P: The management plan includes continued administration of isotonic saline at a reduced rate of 60 mLhr, potassium repletion, and insulin therapy with a bolus followed by continuous infusion. Fluid balance will be closely monitored to maintain a negative balance, and urine output will be checked hourly. The patient will be educated on the signs and symptoms of diabetes and its management, including dietary recommendations. Referral to an endocrinologist for diabetes management and follow-up on dengue treatment with an infectious disease specialist is planned. Compliance with the treatment regimen and close monitoring in the hospital setting will be crucial for recovery.

S: The patient reports persistent hoarseness and dysphagia for three months following an upper respiratory infection. The patient has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast, treated with mastectomy two years ago. No new symptoms were reported besides the existing hoarseness and difficulty swallowing.
O: Clinical examination revealed right vocal cord paralysis. CT scan showed an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple bilateral nodules. Fine needle aspiration FNA of a right-sided 3.5 cm thyroid nodule was initially diagnosed as atypia of undetermined significance Bethesda category III and later as a benign follicular nodule Bethesda category II. Right thyroid lobectomy and right vocal cord injection were performed the lobectomy specimen measured 4.6 cm and weighed 16 grams. Histologic examination indicated nodular thyroid hyperplasia and multiple subcentimeter foci of metastatic breast carcinoma in 7 out of 16 tissue sections, with the largest metastatic focus measuring 0.6 cm.
A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast carcinoma to the thyroid, presenting with nodular thyroid hyperplasia and right vocal cord paralysis. Differential diagnosis initially included benign thyroid nodules and potential primary thyroid malignancies, which were ruled out by histopathological examination. The presence of metastatic breast carcinoma in the thyroid is a significant finding, indicating systemic spread.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patients condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any progression of metastatic disease or emergence of new symptoms. The patient will be referred to oncology for further evaluation and management of metastatic breast carcinoma. Symptomatic treatment for hoarseness and dysphagia, including possible speech therapy, will be considered. The patient is advised to maintain regular communication with the healthcare team and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reported a history of a strangulated large bowel and ventral hernia, which occurred 10 years after a Laparoscopic Adjustable Gastric Banding LAGB procedure. The patient also mentioned a subsequent LAGB port-site infection, which required removal of the port. O: Past surgical interventions include emergency surgical hernia repair with resection of necrotic transverse colon and creation of a loop ileostomy, removal of an infected LAGB port, and a right hemicolectomy with removal of the gastric band and tubing, followed by creation of an end ileostomy. CT scans previously showed LAGB tubing in a stable position without penetration concerns. Recent complications include abdominal sepsis due to transection of the transverse colon by LAGB tubing.
A: The primary diagnosis is complications from LAGB, including abdominal sepsis and mechanical bowel obstruction due to transection by the LAGB tubing. Differential diagnoses previously considered include hernia and infection related to surgical sites and devices.
P: The management plan includes close monitoring for complications and ensuring proper healing post-recent surgeries. The patient is advised to follow post-operative care instructions closely and report any unusual symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and address any arising issues. The patient is encouraged to maintain communication with the healthcare team to facilitate ongoing care and support.

S: The patient, who has a history of beta thalassemia intermedia treated with biweekly blood transfusions and chelation therapy DFO and deferiprone, reports experiencing metamorphopsia and gradually worsening reduced visual acuity in both eyes over the past four months. SD-OCT showed a subfoveal hyperreflective deposit and mild stippling in the macular area. Fluoroscein angiography indicated staining of the macular lesion in late phases. Ferritin levels are within normal limits.

P: Plan to perform a full-field electroretinogram to assess retinal function and confirm DFO retinopathy. Based on the results, treatment options and follow-up care will be discussed. The patient is advised to schedule a follow-up appointment after the electrophysiology testing to review results and plan further management. Continuation of current systemic treatments for beta thalassemia intermedia and hypothyroidism should be maintained.

Accompanying symptoms include dyspnea, nausea, and sweating. The patient has a familial history of hypertension, is a former smoker quit 17 months ago, and does not consume alcohol. Current medications include captopril, bisoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, warfarin, isosorbide dinitrate, and atorvastatin. The patient admits to non-compliance with the warfarin regimen.
O: Vital signs are within normal limits: blood pressure 11080 mmHg, heart rate 54 bpm, respiratory rate 22min, and temperature 37 C. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings reveal a suboptimal INR of 1.28, elevated triglycerides at 273 mgdL, with normal LDL, HDL, complete blood count, urea, creatinine, AST, ALT, CK-MB, and hs-troponin T levels. Coronary Angiography indicates an ectatic and turbulent mid-distal right coronary artery with slow flow.
A: The patient presents with unstable angina, likely secondary to ectatic coronary artery disease, compounded by non-compliance with anticoagulant therapy warfarin. Differential diagnoses include acute coronary syndrome and myocardial infarction, although normal hs-troponin T levels are reassuring against acute myocardial injury.
P: Management includes a loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel, administration of fondaparinux, and strict adherence to the existing medication regimen, especially warfarin, with close monitoring of INR levels. The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments for further evaluation and management, including potential adjustments in therapy based on symptomatic response and diagnostic findings. Education on the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modification for cardiovascular risk reduction is emphasized.

Treatment includes anticoagulation therapy for pulmonary embolism and potential intervention for gastrointestinal leak if confirmed. The patient will be monitored for any changes in the mass or symptoms such as discomfort or pain. Follow-up appointments will be arranged post-imaging and biopsy results to discuss treatment strategies. The patient is advised to contact the clinic if she has any concerns or new symptoms in the meantime.

S: Patient reports recurrent amnesia upon waking with disorientation and repetitive questioning, lasting a few minutes. Additionally, experiences 30-second trance-like episodes during the day, sometimes with repetitive swallowing movements, followed by disorientation and repetitive questioning, occurring in clusters of up to seven per day. Patient has partial recollection of these episodes. Reports loss of newly acquired memories, difficulty recalling autobiographical events, and familiar routes. Also experiences olfactory hallucinations smelling like candy floss, blunted sense of smell, headaches with migrainous features, postural arm tremor, tingling in legs, malaise, and low mood. Medical history includes depression and heavy alcohol use.
O: Brain MRI showed subtly increased T2 signal in the right hippocampus. EEG was normal. Clinical examination revealed no focal neurological signs. Patient has been on lamotrigine, starting at 25 mg and increased to 100 mg twice a day, which resolved the trance-like and amnestic attacks. Other symptoms persist.
A: Primary diagnosis of Transient Epileptic Amnesia TEA based on clinical presentation and response to lamotrigine. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of epilepsy, transient ischemic attacks, or psychological factors contributing to memory loss. The prognosis is generally favorable with appropriate management of epilepsy, but ongoing monitoring is required due to the complexity of symptoms.
P: Continue lamotrigine at the current dosage and monitor patients response. Further investigate persistent symptoms like headaches, tingling, and olfactory hallucinations to refine treatment. Encourage patient to keep a symptom diary for better management and follow-up. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate patient on the importance of medication adherence and reporting new or worsening symptoms.

S: Patient reports constant blurry vision in the left eye for approximately 6 weeks. Medical history includes cystic fibrosis, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, chronic sinusitis, hypertension, iron deficiency anemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. Patient underwent sinus surgery 7 months ago and is currently on multiple medications including albuterol, azithromycin, itraconazole, insulin, lisinopril, pancreatic enzymes, and sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. Denies use of tobacco or drugs.

Optical coherence tomography shows mild intraretinal and trace subfoveal fluid in the left eye. Fluorescein angiogram indicates delayed venous filling in the inferior venous arcade. Blood pressure readings over the past year range from 11070 to 14585. Recent hemoglobin A1c was 6.9. Laboratory workup shows normal complete blood cell count, Vitamin A and D levels, coagulation profiles, and negative prothrombin G20210A mutation. Mild elevation in glucose at 121 mgdL and weakly positive antinuclear antibody at 2.
A: Primary diagnosis is branch retinal vein occlusion BRVO in the left eye, likely exacerbated by underlying hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Differential diagnoses could include diabetic retinopathy or other vascular occlusive disorders. The prognosis depends on the management of underlying conditions and response to treatment.
P: Plan to monitor blood pressure and glucose levels closely. Initiate or adjust antihypertensive and diabetic medications as needed. Refer to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and possible intravitreal injections or laser therapy for BRVO. Educate patient on the importance of controlling blood pressure and blood sugar levels to prevent progression of ocular and systemic complications. Schedule follow-up in 1 month to reassess condition and treatment efficacy. Encourage patient to report any worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of multiple chronic conditions including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease, presents with a two-month history of pain in the umbilical hernia region, exacerbated by food intake. Surgical intervention herniorrhaphy was performed, and histopathological analysis identified malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemistry results were positive for pancytokeratin and CK7, negative for CK20, CDX2, TTF-1, and PSA. Lab tests showed elevated CA 19-9 16,590 UmL, normal 37 UmL and CEA 14.2 ngmL, normal 0-5 ngmL. CT imaging with contrast highlighted a 5.0  2.7 cm mass in the pancreatic tail and body, with vascular involvement and peritoneal carcinomatosis. Comparison with a prior CT scan showed progression from an isolated umbilical hernia to extensive abdominal involvement.
A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatic adenocarcinoma with metastasis, indicated by peritoneal carcinomatosis and liver lesions. The rapid progression from an isolated hernia to extensive malignancy is concerning and suggests an aggressive tumor phenotype.
P: The patients management plan will involve consultation with a multidisciplinary team to discuss potential treatments including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and possibly surgery. The patient will be closely monitored for symptom management and advised on nutritional support to address weight loss. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment response and adjust the care plan as necessary. The patient will also be provided with psychological support and counseling to help cope with the diagnosis and treatment process.

Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to ensure proper recovery and to discuss further reproductive health management.

S: The patient, a 13-year-old with a history of ASD, developmental delay, and hypotonia, reports being born at term by caesarean section, weighing 6 lb, 14 oz. The patient has a history of grade five vesicoureteral reflux with a dysplastic left kidney, absence seizures at 3 months and 9 years, delayed myelination, hypoplastic olfactory nerves, Klippel-Feil anomaly, and incomplete myelin maturation in the brain. Growth parameters were consistently at or below the third percentile, with severe constipation and delayed developmental milestones. No specific genetic diagnosis was identified in early assessments, but recent whole genome sequencing revealed a de novo KMT2A frameshift variant.

A: The patient is diagnosed with Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome WSS, characterized by the clinical features and genetic findings. The differential diagnosis includes other genetic syndromes with overlapping features, but the genetic testing supports WSS. The patients history of developmental challenges and neurological issues are consistent with this diagnosis.
P: Continue current medications, including risperidone, and behavioral therapy. Monitor growth and developmental progress regularly. Consider consultation with a gastroenterologist for severe constipation management and a neurologist for ongoing neurological assessment. Educate the patient and family about Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome and discuss potential complications and management strategies. Regular follow-ups to reassess the treatment efficacy and make adjustments as necessary.

Initially, FiO2 was 80 with a PaO2 of 65 mmHg. After applying lung protective strategies and other treatments, the patient was weaned from mechanical ventilation on the fifth ICU day. Neurological examination post-weaning showed left facial paralysis with no other abnormalities cranial CT and MRI were normal. Dermatological examination revealed facial oedema, pustular lesions, and a tongue fissure. Labium mucosal biopsy confirmed mucositis.

The differential diagnosis initially included other causes of facial swelling and paralysis, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings.
P: The patient was prescribed intravenous methylprednisolone 1 mgkg for PFP and transferred to the neurology department for ongoing management of MRS. The treatment plan includes monitoring, adjustment of therapies as needed, and supportive care for symptoms of mucositis and respiratory distress. Further consultations with dermatology and possibly rheumatology are recommended to manage the complex presentation of MRS. Education regarding the chronic nature of MRS and strategies for managing exacerbations will be provided.

S: 50-year-old Chinese male presents with a one-month history of fever, headache, and vomiting. No prior illnesses reported.
O: MRI brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. CT thorax shows a 6.5 cm x 4.5 cm mass in the right upper lobe. Lumbar puncture shows raised intracranial pressure 26 cm H2O, elevated CSF cell count 260 cellsmm3, 90 lymphocytes, low glucose 1.9 mmolL, and raised protein 1.15 gL. CSF and blood cryptococcal antigen positive, CSF fungal culture positive for C. gattii. HIV test negative. S: A 52-year-old female presented to the emergency room with a 2-day history of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation. She also reported abdominal bloating and discomfort. No past medical or surgical history was noted.
O: Physical examination revealed discomfort on deep abdominal palpation without peritoneal signs. Laboratory tests showed a mildly elevated white blood cell count and low potassium levels, which were corrected. A computed tomography scan and a small bowel follow-through indicated a small bowel obstruction with moderate stomach distention and multiple distended small bowel loops, with no contrast seen in the cecum at 14 hours post ingestion.
A: The primary diagnosis is small bowel obstruction, confirmed by imaging and surgical findings. The obstruction was caused by the ingestion of a pineapple core, which was surgically retrieved. No other differential diagnoses are currently considered.
P: The patient was admitted for surgical intervention, specifically an exploratory laparotomy, which successfully retrieved the obstructing foreign body. Post-operatively, the patient is under observation with plans for discharge pending continued recovery and absence of complications. Education on dietary habits and potential risks of ingesting indigestible materials was provided to prevent recurrence.

Heart function is normal as per echocardiography.

Preoperative instructions will be provided, and surgery will be scheduled promptly. The patient is advised to follow preoperative guidelines and reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient, a long-term heavy smoker, presented with worsening hoarseness over the last 8 months, accompanied by dysphagia and a sensation of a foreign body in the throat. The patient has a history of arterial hypertension treated with beta blockers.

Histopathological examination post-biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the glottic region, affecting the anterior commissure and infiltrating the left and part of the right vocal cord. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess healing and detect any recurrence early. The patient is advised to cease smoking and reduce alcohol consumption to mitigate further health risks. Psychological support and speech therapy will be provided to assist in recovery and adaptation post-laryngectomy.

FSH level was 1.3 IUL.

P: Continue close monitoring in the neonatal intensive care unit with ongoing mechanical respiratory support. Plan for further endocrinological evaluation and genetic testing to clarify the diagnosis. Regular follow-up appointments with pediatric endocrinology are necessary to manage and adjust treatment as needed. Educate the parents about the condition and the importance of follow-up care. S: The patient is a 72-year-old female with stage IV melanoma pT2a, N3c, M1d AJCC 2017 presenting with a bulky ulcerated tumor mass on her right upper leg. She reports worsened leg pain following the initiation of immunotherapy. She has an asymptomatic singular brain metastasis and suspected tumor lesions in the chest, iliac, inguinal, and lung areas. No history of chills, fever, weight loss, or malaise is reported.
O: Physical examination revealed a bulky ulcerated tumor on the right upper leg. Laboratory findings include elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase LDH at 566 Ul normal range: 135214 Ul and S100B level at 0.63 gl normal  0.2 gl. Massive leucocytosis 68,970l normal range: 4,6009,500l with neutrophilia 63,420l normal range: 1,8007,200l and elevated CRP at 53 mgl normal  0.5 mgl were noted. Blood smears showed no signs of leukemia. Staphylococcus aureus was identified from wound swabs of the ulcerated tumor. BRAF, NRAS, and KIT mutation analysis showed gene wild-types.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage IV melanoma with complications including a Staphylococcus aureus infection at the tumor site and systemic inflammatory response indicated by leucocytosis and elevated CRP. Differential diagnosis includes potential progression of melanoma or side effects from immunotherapy.
P: The treatment plan includes combination therapy with ipilimumab 3 mgkg body weight and nivolumab 1 mgkg body weight, approved for BRAF V600 wild-type, unresectable or metastatic melanoma. Radiotherapy is planned for the brain lesion and the bulky mass on the right upper leg. For the Staphylococcus aureus infection, intravenous clindamycin 600 mg three times daily over 10 days has been administered. Continuous monitoring of blood parameters and tumor response will be conducted, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing limiting angina despite being on maximally titrated medical therapy. The patient confirms a history of coronary artery disease CAD, hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia. The patient has undergone coronary artery bypass graft CABG 15 years ago and a redo CABG 2 years ago. The patient also has a history of multiple stents and bilateral carotid endarterectomy.
O: The patient is on a comprehensive cardiac medication regimen including aspirin, prasugrel, carvedilol, ranolazine, sustained-release isosorbidemononitrate, atorvastatin, lisinopril, a nitroglycerin patch, and as-needed sublingual nitroglycerin. A coronary angiography performed 4 months ago revealed a 95 stenosis in the mid-left anterior descending artery LAD, extending past the left internal mammary artery LIMA anastomosis. A Synergy drug-eluting stent was successfully deployed in the mid-LAD with no residual stenosis, although a slight kink in the distal one-third of the stent at the LIMA insertion point was noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is severe coronary artery disease with a history of multiple revascularizations and complex stent placements. The patients symptoms of angina despite maximal medical therapy and recent stent placement suggest advanced and possibly refractory CAD. Differential diagnoses could include progression of CAD or stent-related complications.

Educate the patient on recognizing signs of worsening cardiac symptoms and the importance of immediate medical attention. Consider consultation with interventional cardiology if there is any change in symptoms or if they worsen, to evaluate the need for further intervention. Encourage lifestyle modifications to support overall cardiovascular health.

S: 60-year-old white British female presents with unilateral ankle pain and swelling, stage-3 acute kidney injury AKI, and haematuria. She reports a recent hospital discharge after treatment for a urinary tract infection UTI and AKI. She confirms treatment with IV fluids, oral Prednisolone, and broad-spectrum antibiotics due to a positive urine dip and microscopy. She experienced two tonic-clonic seizures following the administration of Daptomycin, which were self-terminating.
O: On examination, no focal neurological deficit was noted. Vital signs showed a mean arterial pressure of 130 mmHg and oxygen saturations between 94-97. Laboratory findings included haemoglobin 105 gL, urea 13.8 mmolL, creatinine 228 micromolL, eGFR 19 mlmin, and C-reactive protein 14 i.u. Liver function tests, calcium, and phosphate levels were normal. A CT scan of the head was performed, and a venous ultrasound-Doppler ruled out deep vein thrombosis DVT. Urine culture grew Glycopeptide-resistant Enterococcus sp.
A: The primary diagnosis is stage-3 AKI with complications including drug-resistant UTI and seizure activity, possibly related to Daptomycin administration. Differential diagnoses previously considered included a flare-up of rheumatoid arthritis and DVT, both of which have been managed or ruled out respectively.
P: Continue monitoring the patients vital signs and renal function closely. Adjust antibiotic therapy based on microbiologist recommendations and seizure management protocols. Discontinue Prednisolone and monitor for any further seizures or adverse drug reactions. Provide patient education on signs of infection, seizure activity, and the importance of reporting new symptoms. Regular follow-ups with Rheumatology and Nephrology are advised to manage underlying chronic conditions and assess renal recovery.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease, reports bilateral vision loss. He is currently on multiple medications including klopidogrel, ramipril, amlodipine, atorvastatin, gliclazide, and metformin. Additionally, he reports a worsening generalized, pruriginous skin eruption post-injection.

Central macular thickness has decreased. Laboratory tests showed mild hyperlipidemia with cholesterol at 241 mgdl normal 200 mgdl and triglycerides at 256 mgdl normal 150 mgdl. Blood glucose was 155 mgdl and HbA1C was 6.6. Dermatological examination revealed a generalized, erythematous rash with umblicated papules. Skin biopsy indicated acquired reactive perforating collagenosis ARPC.
A: Primary diagnosis of ARPC, likely induced by intravitreal RAN injections, with secondary complications of mild hyperlipidemia and poorly controlled diabetes. The patients vision improvement in the right eye is encouraging, but the left eye remains significantly impaired.
P: Continue monitoring vision and adjust intravitreal treatment as necessary while managing ARPC with 22 sessions of NBUVB therapy. Address hyperlipidemia and diabetes control through medication adjustment and dietary consultation. Regular follow-ups in ophthalmology and dermatology are recommended to monitor progress and manage side effects.

S: The patient reports a 3-month history of right knee pain without any preceding trauma or excessive exercise. The patient denies any joint locking or palpable mass and has no significant past medical history.
O: Physical examination revealed joint effusion and limited range of motion in the right knee. MRI findings indicated an intra-articular lesion near the posterior cruciate ligament, showing iso-intensity or lower intensity on T1 weighted images and high signal intensity on T2 weighted images. Arthroscopy confirmed synovial hyperplasia and a mass in front of the right posterior cruciate ligament. Biopsy of the lesion showed a bland fibroblastic proliferation with no signs of malignancy. Immunohistochemistry was positive for SMA and negative for S100, desmin, and CK.
A: The primary diagnosis is a benign fibroblastic proliferation in the right knee, likely a nodular fasciitis based on histology and immunohistochemistry results. Differential diagnoses such as synovial chondromatosis, pigmented villonodular synovitis, and malignant soft tissue tumor were considered but ruled out based on biopsy and immunohistochemistry.
P: The patient underwent successful arthroscopy with lesion excision and partial synovectomy. The plan includes monitoring the patients recovery and regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new concerns or changes in symptoms immediately. Further treatment or intervention will be based on the patients progress and any new findings during follow-up.

S: The patient is a 36-year-old female with a history of Congenital Insensitivity to Pain with Anhidrosis CIPA, presenting for revision of left total hip arthroplasty. She reports recurrent episodes of unexplained fever, anhidrosis, burns, and bone fractures since birth. She actively manages her risk of hyperthermia through body surface cooling, maintaining her body temperature at approximately 36C. She has undergone multiple surgeries, including 7 for spinal deformity and bilateral total hip arthroplasty.
O: The patients weight is 50 kg, and height is 147 cm. Recent surgical monitoring showed stable vital signs with a noted increase in systolic blood pressure from 130 to 145 mmHg and heart rate from 60 to 95 bpm immediately post-intubation, which later stabilized. Hemoglobin level was mildly low at 10.6 gdl. No abnormalities were detected in chest radiographs and electrocardiograms. During surgery, no circulatory changes associated with pain were observed, and hemodynamics remained stable.
A: Primary diagnosis is CIPA with complications including recurrent bone fractures and requirement for multiple orthopedic surgeries. Differential diagnosis should consider other neuropathies, but clinical history and presentation strongly support CIPA. Prognosis includes ongoing risk of injuries related to insensitivity to pain and temperature, necessitating continuous monitoring and preventive care.
P: Post-operative management includes routine monitoring of vitals and recovery progress, with specific attention to signs of infection or mechanical issues with the hip prosthesis due to her condition. Continue to manage anemia with appropriate nutritional support and possibly supplementation. Educate on the importance of temperature regulation and injury prevention. Schedule follow-up appointments for post-operative assessment and long-term management of CIPA. No opioid analgesics are required due to her condition. Referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and family planning advice is recommended.

S: The patient, a young individual with no significant past medical history, presented to the emergency department following a witnessed seizure at home, described by the patients mother as involving shaking and incontinence, lasting one to two minutes. The patient reported feeling unwell with symptoms of an upper respiratory infection, including cough and nasal congestion, for the past two to three days. The patient also noted a decreased appetite and a limited diet, primarily consisting of French fries, with efforts to maintain hydration through Gatorade and Pedialyte. The patient has an allergy to amoxicillin, which causes hives, and there is a family history of hypertension but no known seizure disorders.
O: Upon arrival, the patient was somnolent, arousable, and confused, indicative of a postictal state. Vital signs were recorded as follows: temperature 38C, heart rate 108 bpm, blood pressure 11170 mmHg, respiratory rate 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 97 on room air. The initial physical examination showed the patient to be drowsy but well-developed.
A: The primary assessment is a first-time seizure, likely related to an acute illness, possibly the reported upper respiratory infection or a related fever. Differential diagnoses could include an underlying neurological disorder or metabolic imbalance. The prognosis depends on further diagnostic results and response to initial management.
P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs and mental status, hydration, and nutritional support. Laboratory tests and possibly neuroimaging will be conducted to investigate the cause of the seizure. Education will be provided to the patient and family about seizure precautions and the importance of a balanced diet. A referral to a neurologist will be considered based on test results. The patient will be observed for any further seizures or deterioration in condition, with instructions given to alert medical staff immediately should symptoms change.

S: The patient reports severe pain in the lower leg following an incident where a golf ball hit him. The patient was approximately 5 meters away from the source of the shot. He denies any relevant medical, family, or psychosocial history.
O: Physical examination was conducted, and an X-ray of the lower leg was performed, revealing a displaced fracture of the distal one-third of the tibia. No other abnormalities were noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is a displaced fracture of the distal tibia. The patients lack of relevant history and the nature of the injury suggest a straightforward traumatic fracture without underlying pathological conditions.
P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with the insertion of an intramedullary nail to stabilize the fracture. Postoperative follow-up appointments are scheduled at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months to monitor healing and recovery. The patient is advised to be cautious and protect the leg during recovery. He is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if he has any concerns or questions during the healing process.

reference_soap:
S: The patient is a 65-year-old male presenting with reduced vision in both eyes. He has a history of small cell lung cancer treated with chemotherapy, pleural effusion, and a mycobacterial infection treated with multiple antibiotics, including ethambutol. He reports a previous adverse reaction to medication, specifically drug-induced hepatitis.
O: On examination, the patients best-corrected visual acuity is 615 in both eyes. Extraocular movements and anterior segment examination are normal. Dilated fundus examination shows no abnormalities. Visual-evoked potential VEP test indicates bilateral optic axonopathy. MRI scan reveals multiple round peripherally enhancing lesions in both cerebral hemispheres and the right cerebellum. Central 30-2 perimetry shows an incomplete left homonymous hemianopia with additional inferior temporal defects in the right eye.
A: The primary diagnosis is ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy, evidenced by reduced visual acuity, abnormal VEP results, and MRI findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of optic neuropathy or central nervous system lesions, but these are less likely given the clinical context and imaging results.
P: The management plan includes discontinuing ethambutol and consulting with the patients primary care physician to discuss alternative treatments for the mycobacterial infection. Further ophthalmologic follow-up is recommended to monitor the progression or improvement of visual symptoms. Patient education regarding the signs of worsening vision and the importance of regular eye examinations will be provided. Referral to a neurologist may be considered for further assessment of the cerebral lesions.

Imaging includes a low-probability VQ scan for pulmonary embolism, severe diffuse myocardial hypokinesis with LVEF of 20-25, and CT abdomen showing generalized lymphadenopathy and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Chest X-ray negative for acute pathology. Rheumatologic workup unremarkable.
A: Primary diagnosis of acute left ventricular failure with secondary pulmonary arterial hypertension. Differential diagnoses include systemic infection or inflammatory process, considering the systemic symptoms and elevated inflammatory markers.
P: Initiated vasopressor support and unfractionated heparin drip. Admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and management. Plan to continue monitoring vital signs, cardiac function, and response to treatment. Adjustments to therapy will be made based on clinical response and ongoing evaluations. Further diagnostic evaluations may be considered to explore underlying causes or contributing factors to the cardiac dysfunction.

S: The patient reports a 4-month history of difficulty swallowing dysphagia without associated pain or hemoptysis. No other symptoms were reported.
O: Clinical examination revealed a bulky mass in the left tonsillar bed without mucosal ulceration or pathological cervical lymph nodes. Further diagnostic imaging with a maxillofacial CT scan and MRI has been recommended.

The absence of pain, ulceration, and pathological lymph nodes is notable, but further imaging is required to refine the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes.
P: Plan to proceed with scheduling a maxillofacial CT scan and MRI to further evaluate the nature of the tonsillar mass and to assist in developing a comprehensive treatment strategy. Follow-up consultation will be arranged to discuss the results of the imaging studies and to determine the appropriate intervention based on those findings.

S: The patient, a 10-year smoker, presents with acute right-sided chest pain radiating to the shoulder, worsening with deep breaths and movement, and alleviated somewhat by leaning forward or lying down. The pain started a day ago and intensified an hour prior to the visit. The patient also reports a dry cough but denies hemoptysis, trauma, difficulty breathing, palpitations, or any significant past medical, surgical, or infectious history. Similar symptoms occurred four years ago but resolved spontaneously without diagnosis.
O: Physical examination shows the patient is awake and alert but experiencing mild to moderate pain. Respiratory rate is elevated at 22-26 breathsminute, oxygen saturation is within normal limits at 97, and pulse rate is slightly elevated at 96 beatsminute. No further diagnostic results available at this time.
A: Differential diagnosis includes pleuritis, pulmonary embolism, and musculoskeletal pain, considering the patients smoking history and symptomatology. The absence of fever, trauma, and chronic disease history directs the initial focus towards acute causes rather than exacerbation of chronic illness.
P: Plan to conduct chest X-ray, ECG, and possibly a CT scan to further evaluate the cause of chest pain. Blood tests including D-dimer, CBC, and cardiac enzymes will be performed to rule out infection, pulmonary embolism, and acute coronary syndrome. Pain management with NSAIDs, as tolerated, and monitoring in the ER setting. Educate the patient on smoking cessation benefits and follow-up based on test results and clinical improvement. Referral to a pulmonologist or cardiologist may be necessary depending on the outcomes of the initial investigations.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old male farmer with a history of HIV-1 infection, reporting right hypochondriac abdominal pain for five days, accompanied by decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and yellowish discoloration of the sclera for the last two days. He denies fever, diarrhea, blurring of vision, odynophagia, or dysphagia. His medical history includes pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonitis treated with co-trimoxazole and prednisolone, and a history of virological failure managed with multiple antiretroviral therapies.
O: Physical examination revealed icterus and tender hepatomegaly. No CMV retinitis was observed on fundoscopy. Laboratory results showed normocytic normochromic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.7 gdl. Total bilirubin was significantly elevated at 9.2 mgdl, AST was elevated at 109 UL, ALT was within normal limits at 41 UL, and ALP was 90 UL. The patients CD4 count and HIV-1 viral load from previous records were 109L and 4.89 log copiesml, respectively.
A: The primary assessment is acute hepatitis, likely drug-induced given the recent change in HAART regimen and elevated liver enzymes. Differential diagnoses include viral hepatitis, biliary tract disease, and other hepatobiliary disorders. The absence of fever and specific infectious symptoms slightly lowers the likelihood of infectious hepatitis.
P: Continue current HAART regimen while monitoring symptoms and liver function closely. Schedule an immediate follow-up for additional hepatic function tests and an abdominal ultrasound to assess liver and biliary tract structure. Educate the patient on the signs of worsening liver disease and the importance of adherence to the prescribed treatment. Consider consultation with a hepatologist if liver enzymes continue to rise or symptoms worsen.

A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent mixed germ cell tumor, predominantly immature teratoma with yolk sac tumor components, FIGO stage IIIC. The patients disease is characterized by recurrent tumor growth despite initial comprehensive treatment, suggesting a high-risk disease with potential for further recurrence.
P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of tumor markers and CT scans to detect any further recurrence early. The patient will continue under close surveillance with follow-up appointments scheduled every three months. Education on symptom awareness and prompt reporting of any changes has been provided. The patient is encouraged to maintain contact with the oncology team for any concerns or symptoms that may arise.

O: Neurological examination revealed weakness in the biceps and triceps, absence of movement in intrinsic hand muscles, wrist extensors, and wrist flexors. Lower extremity examination showed trace movements in hamstrings and no movements in quadriceps, anterior tibialis, gastrocnemius, or intrinsic foot muscles. Sensory examination indicated normal small fiber modalities but profoundly abnormal large fiber modalities, with absent joint position sense at toes and left ankle, and reduced at both knees. Compound muscle action potential CMAP and sensory nerve action potential SNAP amplitudes were unobtainable, except for a markedly reduced axillar nerve CMAP. CMT Neuropathy score was 28 out of 36, indicating severe neuropathy.
A: The patient presents with severe congenital motor and sensory neuropathy, likely Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, given the chronicity, pattern of motor and sensory deficits, and diagnostic findings. Differential diagnoses may include other forms of hereditary neuropathies or motor neuron diseases, but these are less likely given the clinical and electrophysiological findings.
P: Continue use of mobility aids and initiate referral to a neurologist specialized in neuromuscular disorders for further evaluation and management. Physical therapy to maintain mobility and prevent complications is recommended. Occupational therapy consultation for assistance with activities of daily living, particularly those requiring fine motor skills. Regular follow-up to monitor progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease and genetic counseling may be beneficial for family planning.

reference_soap:
S: The patient reports a high voltage electrical burn on the scalp treated with dressing for 10 days at another hospital. He now presents with a fever and an infected wound on the scalp. He denies any history of immune compromise.
O: The patient exhibits signs of a potentially infected and gangrenous scalp wound. Planned interventions include scalp debridement, clinical examination for hyphae and gangrenous changes, and a tissue biopsy for histopathology to confirm the presence of A. corymbifera. Initial treatment with intravenous amphotericin B is noted.
A: The primary diagnosis is an invasive fungal infection, likely zygomycosis, secondary to a high voltage electrical burn with subsequent wound infection. Differential diagnosis includes other types of fungal infections affecting immunocompetent individuals. The prognosis depends on the response to antifungal treatment and surgical management.
P: Immediate management includes surgical debridement of the scalp and administration of intravenous amphotericin B for a total of 6 weeks. A tissue biopsy will be conducted during the debridement to identify the specific fungal pathogen. Post-debridement, the patient will undergo a clinical examination two days later to assess for further fungal growth and tissue viability. If the infection resolves, a free anterior lateral thigh flap will be used to cover the scalp defect, with recipient vessels being the superior temporal artery and vein. Continuous monitoring and follow-up are essential to ensure the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, was admitted for an open reduction and internal fixation of an ankle fracture and received unfractionated heparin for DVT prophylaxis. On the fourth day post-operation, the patient developed acute shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypoxemia, leading to a diagnosis of DVT and a subocclusive saddle-shaped pulmonary embolism. The following day, the patient experienced sudden left-sided weakness and rightward gaze deviation, indicative of an acute ischemic stroke. The patient reports these symptoms were confirmed by CT angiogram and MRI, showing right-sided common carotid artery occlusion and a tandem occlusion of the inferior branch of the right middle cerebral artery.
O: Initial platelet count was 153,000L, which dropped to 94,000L post-thrombectomy, raising suspicion for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia HIT. However, PF4-H AB and SRA tests were negative, and platelet count improved to 105,000L. The patient was restarted on a therapeutic continuous heparin infusion. A transthoracic echocardiogram with a bubble study revealed a patent foramen ovale with right to left shunting, suggesting a paradoxical embolism as the cause of the stroke. The patients platelet count later downtrended to 36,000L.
A: The primary diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke secondary to a paradoxical embolism through a patent foramen ovale, complicated by a pulmonary embolism and DVT. Differential diagnosis included HIT, which was ruled out with negative PF4-H AB and SRA tests. The patients fluctuating platelet count remains a concern for ongoing monitoring.
P: Continue monitoring the platelet count and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary. Maintain therapeutic heparin infusion while monitoring for any signs of bleeding or thrombocytopenia. Consider consultation with a hematologist for platelet management and a cardiologist for evaluation of the patent foramen ovale. Educate the patient on the signs of stroke recurrence and the importance of adhering to the anticoagulation therapy regimen. Schedule follow-up appointments for continuous assessment and management of the patients complex conditions.

S: The patient, with a history of macrocephaly and ataxia, reports a 6-week duration of balance and coordination difficulties and peripheral vision loss. No significant past medical history was noted.
O: Initial examination excluded papilledema but indicated mild peripheral vision loss. Brain MRI revealed a large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass centered within the hypothalamusoptic chiasm, measuring 5.4cm x 3.4cm x 5cm, affecting the midbrain and third ventricle, causing obstructive hydrocephalus. Endoscopic biopsy and septostomy were performed, and a right-sided ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed. Pathology confirmed a low-grade glioma, BRAF-V600E negative on immunohistochemistry but positive on next-generation sequencing. Rapid tumor progression and worsening hydrocephalus were noted six weeks into chemotherapy with vincristine and carboplatin. Complications included progressive right-sided hemiparesis, bitemporal hemianopia, central hypothyroidism, and feeding difficulties requiring a gastrostomy tube and a second VP shunt placement. After starting dabrafenib at 5.25mgkgday, the tumor size decreased significantly to 2.5cm x 3.5cm x 2.7cm over three months, with continued decline until plateauing after two years.
A: Diagnosis of low-grade glioma with complications including obstructive hydrocephalus, right-sided hemiparesis, bitemporal hemianopia, central hypothyroidism, and feeding difficulties. The patient showed significant improvement with dabrafenib therapy after chemotherapy failure.
P: Discontinue chemotherapy and continue treatment with dabrafenib at 5.25mgkgday. Monitor tumor progression, neurological status, and endocrine function regularly. The patient no longer requires the gastrostomy tube. Continue rehabilitation for motor and speech skills, and provide supportive care as needed. Regular follow-ups in the neuro-oncology clinic are scheduled to adjust treatment based on response and side effects.

S: The patients mother reports that her son, the second child, has experienced developmental delays, notably in walking and speaking, which began at 14 months. He currently lacks knowledge of the alphabet, colors, or numbers. The family history includes a maternal male first cousin with learning disabilities. The patient had a prenatal history of maternal chlamydia infection treated with antibiotics. He was born prematurely at 37 weeks, with a low birth weight, and required extended NICU care including nasogastric feeds and phototherapy. He was diagnosed with global developmental delay, has been receiving early intervention services since age 2, and is currently in special education with ongoing speech and occupational therapies. He can understand directions and identify body parts. There is also a history of anemia.
O: Physical examination revealed features such as a low anterior hairline, downward slanting palpebral fissures, infraorbital puffiness, overfolded helices, a broad nasal bridge, a wide grin, and a thin upper lip, resembling maternal features. Genetic testing showed normal Fragile X with 29 CGG repeats. Chromosomal microarray analysis CMA detected a heterozygous 1.21 Mb deletion on chromosome 3q29.
A: The primary diagnosis is global developmental delay, likely associated with the chromosomal deletion detected 3q29 deletion syndrome, which can explain the developmental delays and dysmorphic features. Differential diagnoses could include other genetic syndromes, but these are less likely given the specific chromosomal finding.
P: The management plan includes continued support through special education and ongoing speech and occupational therapy. Regular follow-up appointments with the genetics team will be scheduled to monitor his development and adjust care as needed. Collaboration with the pediatrician to manage his anemia and overall health will continue. The family will be educated about the genetic findings and implications for care and development. Regular updates and consultations with the clinical genetics team are advised to ensure comprehensive care and support for the patient and his family.

S: Patient presents with persistent hematochezia, lower abdominal pain, and nonbloody emesis for one month. Reports intermittent rectal bleeding for years, but never continuously for a whole month. Denies recent fevers, weight changes, or antibiotic use. Has moderate Hemophilia A with factor activity between 1-5, prescribed Recombinant human factor VIII, but compliance with visits has been poor. No previous colonoscopy.
O: Physical exam revealed tachycardia and tenderness in the lower abdomen. Positive fecal occult blood test. Lab results showed hemoglobin at 11 gdL, normal PTPTTINR, elevated C-reactive protein at 57.8 mgL, ESR at 21 mmhr, and albumin at 3.5 gdL. CT imaging indicated abnormal colonic thickening. Colonoscopy and biopsies confirmed chronic active ulcerative colitis.
A: Diagnosis of chronic active ulcerative colitis, complicated by underlying moderate Hemophilia A. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding and inflammation, but these were ruled out by imaging and biopsy.
P: Initiated treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone 40 mg every six hours for six days, followed by 60 mg daily until discharge. Also prescribed budesonide 9 mg orally once daily, mesalamine 800 mg three times a day, and pantoprazole 40 mg daily during the 14-day hospital stay. Metronidazole 500 mg was administered intravenously once daily for six days, then orally every eight hours until discharge. Emphasized the importance of compliance with prescribed treatments and follow-up visits.

A: The primary diagnosis was a suspicious melanocytic lesion, with a differential diagnosis of early evolving melanoma in situ, which could not be excluded initially. The absence of a melanocytic lesion in the re-excised sample suggests successful removal of the atypical cells.
P: The patient will undergo regular skin monitoring to detect any new changes or recurrence. The patient has been advised to self-monitor and report any unusual skin changes immediately. Early detection and intervention strategies were emphasized for ongoing management. Further dermatological consultations will be scheduled as needed to ensure continued vigilance.

S: The patient reports a 3-month history of itchy eruptions on the neck and upper back. P: Initiate treatment with doxycycline, monitoring for improvement in the lesions. If there is no significant improvement, reassessment and consideration of alternative therapeutic options will be necessary. The patient is advised to keep the affected area clean and avoid known irritants. Follow-up is recommended to monitor progress and manage any potential complications. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or lack of improvement promptly.
